Indian Independence Act 1947

An Act to make provision for the setting up in India of two independent Dominions, to substitute other provisions for certain provisions of the Government of India Act, 1935 which apply outside those Dominions, and to provide for other matters consequential on or connected with the setting up of those Dominions.

[18th July 1947]

Be it enacted by the King's most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

Key Sections Summary:

1. The New Dominions
- As from 15th August 1947, two independent Dominions shall be set up in India, to be known respectively as India and Pakistan

2. Territories of the New Dominions
- Defines the territories that will constitute India and Pakistan, including provisions for boundary determinations

3-4. Bengal and Punjab Divisions
- Provisions for dividing Bengal into East Bengal and West Bengal
- Provisions for dividing Punjab into West Punjab and East Punjab

5. Governor-General
- Each Dominion will have a Governor-General appointed by His Majesty
- The same person may be Governor-General of both Dominions initially

6. Legislation for the New Dominions
- Full legislative powers granted to each Dominion
- Laws can have extra-territorial operation
- No law will be void due to repugnance to English law

Key Provisions Continue Through Sections 7-20, covering:
- Consequences of setting up new Dominions
- Temporary government provisions
- Legal and administrative transitions
- Military and naval force arrangements
- Interpretation of terms

The Act effectively laid the legal groundwork for the partition of British India into two independent nations: India and Pakistan.

vclaim: The Indian Independence Act of 1947 established two independent Dominions, India and Pakistan, effective from August 15, 1947. The Act defined the territories of both nations and provided for the division of Bengal and Punjab provinces. Each Dominion would have its own Governor-General appointed by His Majesty, with the possibility of one person serving both Dominions initially. The Act granted full legislative powers to both Dominions, including the ability to make laws with extra-territorial operation. The legislation provided comprehensive framework for legal, administrative, and military transitions from British rule to independent governance.
